Dan's corollary to Singer's drowning child analogy - the daisy chain.
Julie is walking along a mountain trail and in the extreme distance visible only by binoculars there's a pond in the valley and a child is drowning in the pond. It's impossible by any physical means for Julie to help the child herself - but by stretch of imagination it so happens that there's an unbroken chain of people behind Julie winding all the way down the mountain trail to a road across the valley that terminates at the pond. Someone explains that if Julie will take the $10 in her pocket and pass it to the person behind her, and he pass it to the person behind him, and so on, then when the $10 gets to the last person who is at the pond's edge, then that person will walk in the pond and save the child. Otherwise if Julie does nothing the child will die.
Pulling her money out - Julie realizes its 10 singles, not a $10 bill, she looks at the long line of people stretching to the pond - there are thousands, maybe tens of thousands - she wonders how many people will pass all 10 bills along, and how many will keep a bill for themselves. Even if all 10 bills make it to the pond, she wonders if the person at the pond's edge will really respond to the money by saving the child, or pocket the money and let the child drown.
Julie's stomach grumbles, she's hungry, and her own son and daughter, walking right in front of her, tell her they are tired. Seeing the drowning child with her binoculars Julie decides to take a risk and separates one of her ten bills and passes it to the person behind her, hoping but not believing it will make it to the pond where it might help the child, and she hopes that more will be inspired to add to her contribution than to pocket it while her dollar passes along the daisy chain, but she puts the other 9 bills back in her wallet and tells her kids to move on so they can finish this hike and go home.

Very important in this debate to distinguish between giving money and giving real resources (e.g. food, shelter, a lift out of a pond, a lifeboat). Give money to people who have no real resources within reach and they are no better off. In other words, it matters what help you provide. If it's just money then you have no control over how it is spent. If it is just spent on food then this might keep people alive who will die only a little bit later in the next famine. If it is spent on food, contraception, and education then perhaps a better outcome will eventually result.

The biggest problem with that lifeboat analogy is really that the developed world generally isn't overpopulated. Europe for instance is far more populated per kilometer than most developed countries. In fact you could make a case for those countries being underpopulated, since historically having large populations have been imported for kickstarted several economic benefits that arise at certain thresholds, beyond which the same thing would be very difficult and improbable.


Some obvious things enabled by population thresholds are: security (big central army prohibits widespread armed opposition), access to a more diverse range of technology and -education (which can be totally non-existent in smaller countries), access to specialists (such as in health care or business), meritocratic opportunities and flexible identity (more people mean more total talent, and so you'll find groups of other people who will share your talent or welcome your particular personality).
But global poverty may be, at least in part, our fault. See Thomas Pogge for details. Hence, we are actually causing harm.

The problem of poverty, as Hank pointed out, is not a problem of resources but of governmental and economic systems. It is not the duty of individuals to help those in extreme poverty, but rather the duty of the collective to band together to create new systems where extreme poverty doesn't exist. So while yes I would save the child and forgo my shoes, after that myself and others also have the duty to prevent future children from falling in the lake and drowning.  Collective preventative action leads to less suffering overall.

This is a really interesting topic that I've thought intensely about since I was a small kid. I can choose to donate time and money, and I do--I have volunteered over 100 hours in my 21 years, started charity events, and given my own money ever since I started a local business at 12 years old. However, this is WAY less than required to ensure a happy and healthy life for every child and family in poverty. It weighed on my conscience once I earned $1,000 and knew I needed to save it if I wanted to go to college to become a genetics counselor. This video helped me flesh out some rationale so I won't lose my mind about not giving away every cent I own:
1) Saving the money for college allows me to pursue a career that would help more families and possibly prevent children's suffering in the long run.
2) After experiencing life-altering health issues that cause my suffering, I need to save everything I have to help prevent my own agony while I convalesce.
3) Giving more than I already have would leave me in poverty, too, as I have very little to donate now. Additionally, I could not ensure the person I donated to would have a good quality of life while sacrificing my own.
4) If I eventually had enough to live comfortably, I could seek to accumulate enough wealth so one or a few more lives could also be comfortable. However, I would not be able to help an entire population, and must live with the fact that I could only help a few.
I'm not sure if these are all solid arguments, but at the very least it can help me stop obsessing over the thought that I haven't done enough.

So, some problems with Singer's logic, as presented in this video (I have no time to read his works). The question of whether to save the child should not be thought of in such callous terms as cost-benefit analysis. When you see someone suffering, you don't stop to consider their value, either to society, the economy, their family, or otherwise. You imagine yourself in the child's place and imagine how awful you'd feel, and morality compels you to help. You know you can, so you do it. And, you know that mud washes off, especially if you clean your shoes quickly. I know all this because I've done it - it was a neighbor's dog, but it was being carried down the river, and I jumped in to save it. I did kick off my shoes first, because I could. No laces = time saved. I also set aside my phone and wallet. No reason to get my credit cards wet. But, my point is, the cost-benefit analysis is nothing compared to the emotional reward of doing the right thing, and making a positive impact on the world. You're lucky when life gives you these opportunities to act.

Now, how is this different from helping someone halfway around the world? There are three salient factors that Singer ignores: trust, scope, and time. When I see a child, or dog, who needs help, I make a split decision, I spend a few minutes of my life helping, and I see my impact immediately, as I carry the wet dog home to his family. When I’m asked to give money to charity… I have to trust that someone really is in need halfway around the world, I have to trust that the charity involved really will help these needy people (the Red Cross has a poor record of using funds efficiently), I have to trust that needed supplies won’t be stolen by some warlord, and I have to trust that while this temporary aid is given, that someone out there will work to improve the situation so that I won’t have to keep giving indefinitely. This requires a great amount of trust – in large numbers of people I’ve never met. And then there’s scope. There isn’t just one needy kid in the world, there are millions of them. Three dollars buys just one net. As a teacher in central Europe, I don’t make that much money, and there’s no way I could buy nets for everyone who needs one, as much as I’d like to. Let me win the lottery one day, and boy-oh-boy, nets for all! So, when countries need millions of dollars, and church fundraisers just won’t do, that’s when I say, this scope requires organized intervention beyond simple charity. It requires government assistance, and this aid has to be more than money, because throwing money at problems is never enough. There has to be effective strategy. It can’t all depend on me.
This is where time comes in. The amount of time required for me to be an active humanitarian, to raise money, to contact my political representatives, to protest and write chain letters begging everyone around me to change laws and agree to work as a nation to help others – this becomes a full-time job. I can’t just jump in some mud and save the entire world. I would if I could. So, if Singer doesn’t recognize these huge factors, that’s not right.

On the other hand, this Hardin fellow… If your boat has room for ten more, then you should bring on ten more people. If that’s the boat’s maximum capacity, then filling it to capacity shouldn’t endanger anyone else onboard the boat – if it does, then blame the boat designers, not the victims sitting on it. I think there is a false equivalence in the Cost/Benefit analysis. The argument seems to be that, in each specific instance of opportunity to help, if cost is low and benefit is high, you must help. The false equivalence seems to be in equating 'low' with 'zero'. Certainly if there is actually zero cost to me, then it could be argued that I am morally obligated; however, life is not a single action. My life will consist of many such opportunities to help people at low cost for high benefit, after all; the error is that adding up a lot of low costs does not guarantee the total cost is low.

(This can be illustrated in defining a 'small number' as a number which is greater than zero but intuitively 'small'. This is analogous to how we define moral concepts - intuitively, rather than discretely. 1 is certainly a small number, as is 2. Adding 1 to a small number should not affect whether or not it is small. When speaking in terms of hard numbers, it becomes obvious that if you add 1 enough times, you will eventually get a number like a billion, which is clearly not small, but you can never pinpoint where it stopped being small along the way, due to your intuitive definition of 'small'.)

So, the question is, am I required, morally, to help people so long as the total cost of my help is 'low' in some definition? And low compared to my own means, or low compared to the value of the benefit they receive, or both? At what point and I morally allowed to stop helping, because the cost stops being 'low', when each individual help is 'low'? Clearly I cannot afford to help every single person in extreme poverty by myself, even if nobody else anywhere is helping; but since each individual person has low cost to the benefit of a saved life, I am individually morally obligated to each of them, by Singer's argument.

This is not to say that 'we can't help everyone so we shouldn't help anyone'. That is clearly not a useful answer... but at the same time, any line we draw as to 'when is it enough' will seem arbitrary at best. 'When you have given enough cost that to give any more would significantly negatively impact you' is an intuitive answer - but when is it significant? Who decides that?

Humans are the only animal who can be induced NOT to do this by artificial (but important) cultural/economic/political factors, which is why SOME human groups (specifically, those in the developed world) reproduce less than others (specifically, those in the developing world). In the absence of such factors, a human group (like any other animal group) will increase in number not just TO the environment's carrying capacity, but BEYOND it, meaning that those who cannot feed themselves or get fed or stay healthy or whatever suffer and die and bring the numbers back down. This mechanism is the only non-arbitrary one that can limit a group's numbers. This is like a law of ecology, from which we like to imagine we're exempt since we like to imagine we're not animals. The weakness in this philosophical argument is that it presumes that human lives have inherent value, both morally and to us as a species. They do not. A human life amounts to what one can feasibly do with that life, whether the one measuring that value is the individual or someone manipulating that individual.

This enters the pitfall of, for example, if you have the option to, at little cost to yourself, ensure a child in your home country has shoes, a winter coat, and better educational opportunities, are you more or less obligated to provide that help than you are to do the same in a a different country?

The moral obligation in that case would be to put your money where it has the greatest chance of yielding positive results. In much the same way that you would not plant food crops in sand when you could plant them in soil, people make a value proposition when making a decision on charity.

Can we end worldwide poverty? Yes. Are we under a moral obligation to do so when there are similarly solvable problems in our own country that could be addressed and would quite arguably produce better long-term results for ourselves, our immediate relatives, and other citizens of our respective homelands? This one is hard to swallow. Ultimately, the reason why it is difficult to provide aid to others happens to be the problem of community. The difference between real life and the thought experiment is that sending aid to other countries changes the power balance between nations. Certainly helping out to some extent has such a negligible impact as to be irrelevant, but on the scale you are suggesting it would cause huge problems.

First, there is the problem of loyalty. Helping someone within your own nation means that you understand you won't ever be helping your enemy. The solidarity of a country is part of the reason a well-established nation can use government resources to provide for its citizens. In dictatorships, the primary reason the citizens are treated so poorly is because if they were healthy and affluent, they would be fighting the dictator. No amount of aid you send to these people will make them better off. They will instead go to the soldiers fighting your country or allies.

Secondly, helping people whom you can not both see and understand is irresponsible. This doesn't mean that we shouldn't help people, it is just that we really do need to see the person we are helping. In other words, a child drowning in front of your eyes is different than one halfway across the world. This is because if you cannot see how you are affecting something, you might actually be contributing to something terrible. Maybe that $3 for a mosquito net bankrupts the mosquito net sellers. Maybe the money isn't buying nets at all. Maybe the nets aren't going to the people you intended to help. Maybe they don't even want mosquito nets if it is coming from your country. There are innumerable uncertainties involved with helping someone you can't see. This is why if you are going to help, you should do it through people you trust and verify the results. In other words, you should ultimately see the person/people you are helping.

It's possible that the either-or "fallacy" brought up here is actually valid. Mathematician Vilfredo Pareto observes that resources tend to be distributed extremely unevenly in societies with property rights. Pareto's law shows that the whole society will be prosperous if and only if its elite are extremely wealthy. Therefore, we must embrace this unevenness in order to maintain prosperity.

If we must make moral consideration worldwide, we should analyze Earth as a single society, still mindful of Pareto's law. This tells us that the challenge of poverty is not the redistribution of wealth, but the creation of new wealth. We must continue to reduce the costs of producing goods and increase the availability of economic opportunity.

In other words, teach a man to fish. And if you feel the need to donate, donate fishing equipment.

The problem with the pond thought experiment is that it presupposes, like many of these ethical thought experiments, that you have perfect knowledge of the consequences of your actions as you're deciding what to do. Unfortunately, that is not how things happen in the real world. The best we can do is go with probable consequences. The probability of saving a life in the case of a child in a pond right in front of us is pretty high, and it's easy for us to gauge that probability. On the other hand, it is much harder to gauge the probability of saving the life of someone we've never seen, and there are many reasons to believe it is less probable (money intended for aid could be diverted or lost due to corruption, incompetence, etc).

In the end, you still do have a moral obligation to save the lives of people even if you don't know them, but it's a much weaker moral obligation (due to the uncertainty) than that of saving the lives of those right in front of you.
